items.title: Suggestion:  csvuniq
items.body:
`csvuniq -c col1,col2,...`  would only keep rows where the tuple `(col1,col2,..)` was unique.
This would keep the first row seen.
It would be up to the user to use `csvsort` beforehand.

items.title: [suggestion] allow wildcard for input files
items.body:
Scenario: a folder full of csv with identical structure (i.e. different annual/monthly/daily reports from an application),

For example it would be great if this command can work:
`csvstack *.csv > total.csv`

Possible issues: deal with duplicated/identical rows.

items.title: csvjson: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'Locale'
items.body:
When using `csvjson` with Python 2.7 I got this error:
```
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'Locale'
```

I traced the issue back to the package `parsedatetime-2.6` that is used by csvkit.

The issue can be fixed by locking that package to version 2.5.

Also see these discussions:
https://github.com/bear/parsedatetime/issues/246
https://github.com/certbot/certbot/issues/8042

I hope that this issue can be useful for others that run into the same problem.

items.title: in2csv adds a .0 decimal at the end of xls files
items.body:
Hi,
I have a problem in the XLS conversion.
Every cell that contains only numbers, even if its format is set to "Text", when is converted add automatically a ".0" at the end.
What can we do? i need to use xls and not xlsx.
To convert my XLS files i use this command:
`in2csv file.xls --no-inference -e utf-8| csvformat -D ";" > test.csv `

Thanks

items.title: New tool suggestion: csvzip
items.body:
Hi there,

We have published a small tool we use in many projects [csvzip](https://github.com/PopulateTools/csvzip) to compress CSVs before publishing them as web visualizations with javascript. It's a very basic technique but very effective to reduce the amount of data browsers have to download.

What the script does is to extract categorical variables to a dictionary and replace those values by integers in the CSV.

If you feel like this could be useful to add in csvkit I'm available to migrate the code from Cystal to Python. Otherwise feel free to close the issue :)

You are doing a great job with csvkit, thank you so mucho for your work and time 💪

items.title: csvsort with an empty column
items.body:
I have a csv file `foo.csv` that looks like this.
```
a,b,c,d,e
C,2020-01-01,foo,,-0.62
C,2020-01-01,foo,,-0.61
```
When I run `csvsort -c e foo.csv`, as expected, I get
```
a,b,c,d,e
C,2020-01-01,foo,,-0.61
C,2020-01-01,foo,,-0.62
```
But when I run `csvsort -c d,e foo.csv`, it reverses the entries. Since the "d" column is blank for both entries, shouldn't they be sorted by the "e" column?
```
a,b,c,d,e
C,2020-01-01,foo,,-0.62
C,2020-01-01,foo,,-0.61
```

How do I disable number formatting with the thousands separator?  When I pipe large numbers through csvlook, it turns "1234567 into "1,234,567" which I can't copy and paste for other purposes as easily.

items.title: csvjoin removes "none" values when joining on other columns
items.body:
Occurs in csvjoin 1.0.5. Doesn't happen in csvcut, it keeps the none values as is

Example:
a.csv
```
id,name,value,fk
1,Foo,"none",2
2,Bar,"some",2
3,Faz,"none",2
4,Baz,"None",2
```
b.csv
```
id,name
1,Somename1
2,Some Name2
```
command: `csvjoin --verbose --no-inference -c "fk,id" a.csv b.csv`
result:
```
id,name,value,fk,name2
1,Foo,,2,Some Name2
2,Bar,some,2,Some Name2
3,Faz,,2,Some Name2
4,Baz,,2,Some Name2
```
I would expect that columns with "none" in them would still contain the value "none" like csvcut does

Occurs when reading a dbf file.
I don't know whether there exists different species of .dbf files, but the ones I am reading are components of an ESRI Shapefile (a geographic information system file format).

items.title: convert csv to TSV?
items.body:
```
csvformat -D $'\t' <<EOF
"a,b","c""d","e
f"
EOF
a,b	"c""d"	"e
f"
```

In the above output, newline character is still used, and \n is also used.

Can the output be a TSV like this (and "\" needs to be escaped as well)?

```
a,b<TAB>c"d<TAB>e\nf
```

items.title: How to get just the row count
items.body:
Ideally I'd want `csvgrep` to directly support the equivalent of  `grep -c` and `grep -q`, but as a poor man's equivalent we are recommended in #441 to pipe to `csvstat --count`.

However, `csvstat --count` outputs extra text (e.g: `Row count: 8`) so it's an extra step just to extract the count out.

Other commands like `csvstat -c foo --sum` simply output the raw number, so it seems the behaviour of `--count` is a little inconsistent as well as being not very useful.

items.title: csvclean using on all files in a directory (possibly feature or bug)
items.body:
Apologies as I am ok on the command line, but not an expert, so this may be something silly or this tool may just not work on multiple CSV files. The files I am using are Google Ads keyword planner outputs that are notoriously difficult to work with as use UTF-16 and tabs with some odd quirks and odd formatting (random rows etc.). All other files I have been using with csvkit have been pretty straight forward. 

`csvclean -e utf-16 -t -K2 example.csv` works very well.

`csvclean csvclean -e utf-16 -t -K2 *.csv` doesn't work as expected as with other commands like stacking files.

Also trying bash code like `for f in *.csv ; do csvclean -e utf-16 -t -K2 $f ; done` doesn't work either or piping into the command or a number of items I tried.

I get the following:

`csvclean csvclean -e utf-16 -t -K2 *.csv` (returns error and all file names)
csvclean: error: unrecognized arguments: Changed Stats 2020-02-19 at 15_17_14.csv Changed Stats 2020-02-19 at 15_17_35.csv

`for f in *.csv ; do csvclean -e utf-16 -t -K2 $f ; done` (returns error and all file names removing the first word)
csvclean: error: unrecognized arguments: Stats 2020-02-19 at 15_21_33.csv

Many thanks in advance, apologies if this is a silly user error issue.

If it helps I've tried using Mac OS X iTerm with both the normal command line environment and switching to conda activate py3.

```
hex1,hex2,vr,description
0018,9080,ST,Metabolite Map Description

0018,9082,FD,Effective Echo Time (0018,9083) SQ Metabolite Map Code Sequence
0018,9084,SQ,Chemical Shift Sequence
```

items.title: csvsql: is it possible to use a csvsql sql statement output to create a table (inferencing related)
items.body:
Hi,
sometimes the field inferencing does not work properly. An example I have is a field with this kind of value - `085232` - that becomes `DECIMAL(38, 0)` and it's converted to 85232.

Then I modify

```sql
CREATE TABLE mytable (
	fieldone VARCHAR(27) NOT NULL, 
	`MYFIELD` DECIMAL(38, 0) NOT NULL, 
);
```

to

```sql
CREATE TABLE mytable (
	fieldone VARCHAR(27) NOT NULL, 
	`MYFIELD` VARCHAR(6) NOT NULL, 
);
```

For me it would be great to use csvsql to create a first version of sql statement, to edit it, and then to have have the opportunity to run something like:

```bash
# create the table if not exist
csvsql --db "mysql+pymysql://user:password@localhost/test" --create-if-not-exists --statement mystatement.sql
# insert the data in the table
csvsql --db "mysql+pymysql://user:password@localhost/test" --tables mytable --insert --overwrite --create-if-not-exists myfile.csv
```

Is there a way, using csvkit, to use a sql statement to create a table?

Thank you

items.title: Please consider cutting a release
items.body: I just ran into a bug that has apparently been [fixed for a long time](https://github.com/wireservice/csvkit/commit/3fee4b03bda058b6e0caed0aca7daea73a115565). It's kind of complicated to move a bunch of production machines from stable packaged releases to git versions. It would be really nice if there was a patch release cut that included at least that, if not other improvements since the last release.

items.title: Fix incorrect normalization of data
items.body:
The handling of [textql](https://github.com/dinedal/textql) looks much more reasonable:

```txt
$ cat a.csv
id,name
1,john
2,lisa

$ cat b.csv
color,date
red,2020-01-01
blue,2020-01-03T14:42:35

$ csvsql --query 'select * from a join b' a.csv b.csv
id,name,color,date
1.0,john,red,2020-01-01 00:00:00.000000
1.0,john,blue,2020-01-03 14:42:35.000000
2.0,lisa,red,2020-01-01 00:00:00.000000
2.0,lisa,blue,2020-01-03 14:42:35.000000

$ textql -header -output-header -sql 'select * from a join b' a.csv b.csv
id,name,color,date
1,john,red,2020-01-01
1,john,blue,2020-01-03T14:42:35
2,lisa,red,2020-01-01
2,lisa,blue,2020-01-03T14:42:35
```

items.title: Proposal: csvsub
items.body:
An idea, have a sed like module within csvkit. This would allow grepping based on columns, and also (more importantly) replacing values in certain columns based on regex.

Must haves:
- Ability to find lines matching the regex (for testing, appreciate this overlaps with csvgrep)
- Ability to replace the found regex

Nice to haves:
- User can provide a list of regex replacements by file
- Ability to use replacement groups

I may have a use-case for this in the near future but logging it here incase someone thinks its needed and wants to take a crack before me!

An example test includes, converting json into csv via in2csv, and then running that output through csvsql. ```
```
import subprocess

table_name = 'demo_table'
path = 'path/to/converted/json/to/csv'
schema_cmd = f'echo $(csvsql --version); cat {path} | csvsql --table {table_name} | sed "s/INTERVAL/VARCHAR/g"'

def generate_schema(command):
    process = subprocess.Popen(command,stdout=subprocess.PIPE, shell=True)
    output, error = process.communicate() 
    schema = output.decode(errors="replace").strip()
    schema= f"DROP TABLE IF EXISTS {table_name}; \n" + schema
    return schema

schema = generate_schema(schema_cmd)

print(schema)
```

items.title: Confusion with STDIN
items.body:
I am using 1.0.3, and I'm trying to run a query using `sql2csv`. Since the query is somewhat complex, I don't want to wrap it in quotes and use the `--query` parameter. Instead, I want to use STDIN.

From the help, I see that "If both FILE and QUERY are omitted, query will be read from STDIN.".

I expected to be able to run:

```
sql2csv --db "mysql+pymysql://root:foo@localhost:3307"
```

And wait for the program to me to enter something, but that doesn't work. Instead it shows:

```
sql2csv: error: You must provide an input file or piped data
```

The documentation should mention that "read from STDIN" means that you have to pipe, because the program could in principle just wait for me to enter data like `cat` does.

I see that [using `-`](https://csvkit.readthedocs.io/en/1.0.3/tricks.html#specifying-stdin-as-a-file) is also possible, but it's not mentioned in the `sql2csv` usage. Would it make sense to explicitly add this?

items.title: csvstat adds commas in numeric outputs
items.body:
I recently updated from v0.9.1 to v1.0.3 and noticed `csvstat` now includes commas to separate number values. It doesn't appear there is a flag to specify all the values as `Text` to disallow csvstat from injecting commas.

As an example, suppose I have `foo.csv`:

```
country_name,token,cardholder_name,identifier,city
US,100,Orisa,5555555555554444,Numbani
Canada,99,McCree,2223000048400011,Château Guillard
GB,98,Zenyatta,4111111111111111,Lijiang Tower
```

Running `csvstat --freq foo.csv` outputs something including the following:

```
  4. identifier: { "5555555555554444": 1, "2223000048400011": 1, "4111111111111111": 1 }
```

That is the ideal styling for output. However, when all of the data is queried with `csvstat foo.csv`:

```
  4. "identifier"

	Type of data:          Number
	Contains null values:  False
	Unique values:         3
	Smallest value:        2,223,000,048,400,011
	Largest value:         5,555,555,555,554,444
	Sum:                   11,889,666,715,065,566
	Mean:                  3,963,222,238,355,188.667
	Median:                4,111,111,111,111,111
	StDev:                 1,671,192,655,285,469.496
	Most common values:    5,555,555,555,554,444 (1x)
	                       2,223,000,048,400,011 (1x)
	                       4,111,111,111,111,111 (1x)
```

That is not ideal and I'd like to discover a way to remove the commas without needing to `sed` away the output. These are being falsely labelled as numbers, even though they should be evaluated as strings. Is there an effective way to correct this?

int

$ echo '[{"int":0},{"int":1}]' | in2csv -f json
int
False
True
workaround: use `-I` 
$ echo '[{"int":0},{"int":1}]' | in2csv --no-inference -f json
int
0
1

items.title: csvsql boolean column incorrect for mssql
items.body:
When I try to generate a create table statement for sql server from a csv file which contains a boolean field, the create table statement uses the "BOOLEAN" datatype, which is not supported by sql server. It should use "BIT".

E.g. a csv file (test.csv) with the following contents:

```
Test
Yes
No
```

When using this commandline:

` csvsql .\test.csv -i mssql`

generates the following statement:

```
CREATE TABLE test (
        [Test] BOOLEAN NOT NULL
);
```

but it should generate this:

```
CREATE TABLE test (
        [Test] BIT NOT NULL
);
```

items.title: Detect and remove UTF-8 BOM
items.body:
The bug is illustrated [with files from this zip](https://github.com/wireservice/csvkit/files/2652481/csvkit-UTF8_BOM-bug.zip)

`example.csv` is a CSV file, saved with UTF-8 with BOM marker and LF linefeeds (the webapp [highrise](https://highrisehq.com) uses this format).

When running `./setup.sh` the file is imported into the user-database, and everything seems fine:

    csvsql 1.0.2
    Python 2.7.15
    ProductName:	Mac OS X
    ProductVersion:	10.13.6
    BuildVersion:	17G3025
    NOTICE:  table "example" does not exist, skipping
    DROP TABLE

However, when running `./test.sh`, the second command fails (and the first and third succeed):

    ----[ select * ]--------------------------------------------
       ﻿FullName   |        Email        
    --------------+---------------------
     Test User    | test@example.com
     Another User | another@example.com
    (2 rows)

    ----[ select FullName, Email ]------------------------------
    ERROR:  column "fullname" does not exist
    LINE 1: SELECT FullName, Email from example;
                   ^
    HINT:  Perhaps you meant to reference the column "example.﻿FullName".
    ----[ select [BOM-marker]FullName, Email ]------------------
       ﻿FullName   |        Email        
    --------------+---------------------
     Test User    | test@example.com
     Another User | another@example.com
    (2 rows)


This is because the first column name is prefixed with the BOM marker, and is demonstrated by the third command. When you copy/paste the output into an editor that shows control characters (TextMate), you see the name of the first column is actually `U&"\FEFFFullName"

When the header columns in the CSV file are double-quoted ("FullName","Email"), the behaviour is different but also undesirable, but I haven't checked that.

The error message could be nicer (non-printable characters could be shown escaped as I did in the third example), but I'm not sure which software part that would have to do...

From **csvkit**, I expect the UTF-BOM marker to be detected and removed.

items.title: Pitch for a -U flag for csvsort  (again?)
items.body:
Thanks for creating this excellent, indispensable toolkit.  I'd like to reprise briefly issue #448 and attempt a case for building `sort -u` or equivalent into `csvsort`.  Here goes...

Here's issue #488's example of a pipeline to get unique values from a column, excluding the column header:

`csvcut -c 4 myfile.csv | sed 1d | sort | uniq`

Sometimes, I need to  re-add the column header after this processing. In a `csvkit` workflow this can be important. For example, if you want to process the resulting list with `csvgrep` to remove blanks you need a column heading or it fails. So, this can mean adding an  `awk` step or similar: 

`csvcut -c 4 myfile.csv | sed 1d | sort | uniq | awk 'BEGIN{print "column_heading"};{print}'|csvgrep -c 1 -i -r "^$"`

To cut this extra processing, an intuitive add in to `csvsort` would be a `-U` flag:

`csvsort -c 4 -U myfile.csv | csvgrep -c 1 -i -r "^$"`

Anyhow, that's my case. Thanks for listening, and of course no offence taken if my proposal is neither desirable nor a priority. Thanks again.

items.title: Convert csv to xml
items.body:
What about a tool to convert a generic CSV to XML? As an addition to [JSON output](https://csvkit.readthedocs.io/en/1.0.3/tutorial/4_going_elsewhere.html#csvjson-going-online).

An XML output example:
```xml
<resultset>
   <row>
      <county>GREELEY</county>
      <item_name>RIFLE,7.62 MILLIMETER</item_name>
   </row>
   <row>
      <county>GREELEY</county>
      <item_name>RIFLE,7.62 MILLIMETER</item_name>
   </row>
   <row>
      <county>GREELEY</county>
      <item_name>RIFLE,7.62 MILLIMETER</item_name>
   </row>
</resultset>
```
The root element name and the element name for the rows might be specified in the command line (by default `resultset` and `row` can be used). The column names are used to output the elements contained value. Hence, these column names should be either conformed to [NCName](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1631396/what-is-an-xsncname-type-and-when-should-it-be-used) (and error should be produces otherwise) or auto-converted to NCName-safe form.

[UPD] no need to support `xsi:nil` since CSV does not support `null` type.

items.title: --date-format argument is unrecognized?
items.body:
Not sure if this is an a code issue or a documentation issue, but trying to use `--date-format` to work with a wonky date format fails any way I try it. I'm running 1.0.2 so it should work. 

What I have is a [table of unsolved homicides](https://github.com/washingtonpost/data-homicides) that has dates formatted as `yyyymmdd`. csvkit doesn't recognize the column as dates at all. My read of [arguments common to all tools](https://csvkit.readthedocs.io/en/1.0.3/common_arguments.html) is that I should be able to use `--date-format '%Y%m%d'` to resolve this. I made a 20 row sample, `morsel.csv` to play with the data a bit.  [Sample is available in a gist](https://gist.github.com/amandabee/bafb5c037ec161cad4b4b0b5eea907c8) if you need test data. I've tried every permutation I can think of:

```
csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date --date-format %Y%m%d
csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date --date-format '%Y%m%d'
csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date --date-format "%Y%m%d"
csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date --date-format=%Y%m%d
csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date --date-format='%Y%m%d'
csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date --date-format="%Y%m%d"

csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date | csvstat --date-format="%Y%m%d"
csvcut morsel.csv -c reported_date | csvstat --date-format %Y%m%d
```

Every time I get the same error: `error: unrecognized arguments: --date-format=%Y%m%d` or `error: unrecognized arguments: --date-format %Y%m%d`.  

I don't know whether the problem is that the documentation is leading me astray or the implementation of `--date-format` is broken. What I actually want to do is replace the `reported_date` with a whole different format and I am pretty sure I can't do that in csvkit anyway, so this might be an academic exercise, but it seems like this should be corrected.

items.title: Loading columns with leading 0's drops data, misinterprets data type
items.body:
Perhaps a niche issue, but since we deal with data from the Census, as well as the City and County - both of which store ID's with leading zero's, this is an important one when using this invaluable tool.

Columns with leading zeros are misinterpreted as INTEGER and as a result lose the leading zero and the data type is set to numeric instead of character (which preserves the leading 0).

Example dataset:
https://www.denvergov.org/opendata/dataset/city-and-county-of-denver-real-property-residential-characteristics

items.title: in2csv: Newline characters inside cells in other formats are preserved unescaped as new lines
items.body:
This is perhaps an unusual edge case, but I've run into it today: When you're making a CSV from another format with in2csv, if a cell has a new line in it, this will be reproduced in the final CSV, with no flags or options in the CLI to escape them. 

For many CSV interpreters, this is no problem, but others, including some fairly prominent ones for R and Python, will choke on this. 

Is this something that might be worth fixing?

items.title: csvsort does not honor quoting requests
items.body:
## Minimal quoting, option 0
```bash
> echo -e "a,b\n4,2\n1,4" | csvsort -u 0
a,b
1,4
4,2
```

## All quoting, option 1
```bash
> echo -e "a,b\n4,2\n1,4" | csvsort -u 1
a,b
1,4
4,2
```
expected:

```bash
"a","b"
"1","4"
"4","2"
```

## Quote non-numeric, option 2
```bash
> echo -e "a,b\n4,2\nfoo,bar" | csvsort -u 2
could not convert string to float: 'a'
```

expected
```bash
"a","b"
4,2
"foo","bar"
```

## Quote None, option 3
```bash
echo -e "a,b\n4,2\n\"foo\",\"bar\"" | csvsort -u 3
a,b
"""foo""","""bar"""
4,2
```

expected
```bash
a,b
4,2
foo,bar
```

Options 1, 2, 3 do not seem to be working.

items.title: csvstat incorrectly identifies column type to be date
items.body:
Given the following input:
```
csvstat << EOF
nonDate
"476-09-04 [proleptic] Untergang des Römischen Reichen"
"1944-06-06 Tag X"
"1990-06-13 Mauerfall"
EOF
```
`csvstat` outputs:
```
  1. "nonDate"

	Type of data:          Date
	Contains null values:  False
	Unique values:         3
	Smallest value:        1944-06-06
	Largest value:         2001-09-04
	Most common values:    2001-09-04 (1x)
	                       1944-06-06 (1x)
	                       1990-06-13 (1x)

Row count: 3
```

Instead of the expected:
```
  1. "nonDate"

	Type of data:          Text
	Contains null values:  False
	Unique values:         3
	Longest value:         52 characters
	Most common values:    476-09-04 [proleptic] Untergang des Römischen Reichen (1x)
	                       1944-06-06 Tag X (1x)
	                       1990-06-13 Mauerfall (1x)

Row count: 3
```

items.title: csvstat chokes on "inf" numbers
items.body:
For the following input CSV (yes, 1 row, 1 column, 1 header):

    headerA
    inf

`csvstat` (no other argument besides input.csv) outputs:

```
  1. "columnA"

	Type of data:          Number
	Contains null values:  False
	Unique values:         1
	Most common values:    [<class 'decimal.InvalidOperation'>]
```

This happens because `python-babel` (in Debian system 2.4.0) number formatting function chokes on Infinity, e.g.:
```
from decimal import Decimal
from babel.numbers import format_decimal
format_decimal(Decimal("Infinity"))
```

`format_decimal` is called from `csvstat.py:269` (in Debian system 1.0.2-1).

Interestingly `csvstat --freq` outputs:
```
{ "Infinity": 1 }
```

items.title: in2csv: Support as input format Markdown tables
items.body:
Following markdown variants support tables

- [**Github Flavoured Markdown**](https://help.github.com/articles/organizing-information-with-tables/)

```
| Command | Description |
| --- | --- |
| git status | List all new or modified files |
| git diff | Show file differences that haven't been staged |

| Left-aligned | Center-aligned | Right-aligned |
| :---         |     :---:      |          ---: |
| git status   | git status     | git status    |
| git diff     | git diff       | git diff      |

```

- [**Gitlab**](https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/blob/master/doc/user/markdown.md)
```
| Left Aligned | Centered | Right Aligned | Left Aligned | Centered | Right Aligned |
| :----------- | :------: | ------------: | :----------- | :------: | ------------: |
| Cell 1       | Cell 2   | Cell 3        | Cell 4       | Cell 5   | Cell 6        |
| Cell 7       | Cell 8   | Cell 9        | Cell 10      | Cell 11  | Cell 12       |
```

- [**CommonMark Table Extension**](https://github.com/webuni/commonmark-table-extension)

- [**php Markdown Extra**](https://michelf.ca/projects/php-markdown/extra/#table)
```
First Header  | Second Header
------------- | -------------
Content Cell  | Content Cell
Content Cell  | Content Cell

| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

| Item      | Value |
| --------- | -----:|
| Computer  | $1600 |
| Phone     |   $12 |
| Pipe      |    $1 |
```

- [**Pandoc Markdown:**  ](http://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#pandocs-markdown) [**Tables – Four kinds** ](http://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#tables)
(consider only pipe tables)
1. Simple Table
```
  Right     Left     Center     Default
-------     ------ ----------   -------
     12     12        12            12
    123     123       123          123
      1     1          1             1

Table:  Demonstration of simple table syntax.
```

2. Multiline Tables
```
-------------------------------------------------------------
 Centered   Default           Right Left
  Header    Aligned         Aligned Aligned
----------- ------- --------------- -------------------------
   First    row                12.0 Example of a row that
                                    spans multiple lines.

  Second    row                 5.0 Here's another one. Note
                                    the blank line between
                                    rows.
-------------------------------------------------------------

Table: Here's the caption. It, too, may span multiple lines.
```

3. Grid Table
```
+---------------+---------------+--------------------+
| Fruit         | Price         | Advantages         |
+===============+===============+====================+
| Bananas       | $1.34         | - built-in wrapper |
|               |               | - bright color     |
+---------------+---------------+--------------------+
| Oranges       | $2.10         | - cures scurvy     |
|               |               | - tasty            |
+---------------+---------------+--------------------+
```

4. Pipe Table (identical to Php Markdown Extra)
```
| Right | Left | Default | Center |
|------:|:-----|---------|:------:|
|   12  |  12  |    12   |    12  |
|  123  |  123 |   123   |   123  |
|    1  |    1 |     1   |     1  |
```

- [**KramDown**](https://kramdown.gettalong.org/quickref.html#tables)

- [**MultiMarkdown**](http://fletcher.github.io/MultiMarkdown-5/tables.html)

items.title: csvstat --names ignores the --skip-lines option
items.body:
csvstat --names ignores the --skip-lines option. It always returns the names from the first row. The regular csvstat features do respect --skip-lines.

For example:

> $ cat a.csv
> a,b,c
> d,e,f,g
> 1,2,3,4
> $ csvstat --names a.csv
>   1: a
>   2: b
>   3: c
> $ csvstat --skip-lines 1 --names a.csv
>   1: a
>   2: b
>   3: c

(Thanks for the great set of csv tools.)
